skill.name: commit-helper
skill.description: Intelligent commit message generation following conventional commit format.
skill.summary: Intelligent commit message generation following conventional commit format.
skill.author: CuriousLearner

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill with no executable code. It provides instructions for AI assistants to help users write better commit messages. No security risks detected.

content.value_statement: Writing good commit messages is hard and time-consuming. This skill analyzes your code changes and generates professional commit messages following best practices.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes staged git changes using git diff --staged
Categorizes commits into types (feat, fix, docs, style, etc.)
Follows conventional commit format with proper structure
Reviews recent commits to match project style
limitations: Requires git to be installed on the system
Only works with staged changes (git add required)
Cannot access git history without git log command
Limited to analyzing code changes, not deployment or build processes

use_cases.title: Write better commit messages
use_cases.description: Generate clear, conventional commit messages that follow best practices and improve project history readability

use_cases.title: Standardize team commits
use_cases.description: Ensure consistent commit message format across team members following conventional commit standards

use_cases.title: Professional OSS commits
use_cases.description: Create properly formatted commits for open source projects that match maintainer expectations

prompt_templates.title: Basic commit generation
prompt_templates.prompt: @commit-helper analyze my staged changes and create a commit message

prompt_templates.title: Specify commit type
prompt_templates.prompt: @commit-helper --type fix create a fix commit message for my staged changes

prompt_templates.title: Add scope to commit
prompt_templates.prompt: @commit-helper --scope api generate a commit for API changes

prompt_templates.title: Review and improve
prompt_templates.prompt: @commit-helper look at recent commits and match the style for my new changes

output_examples.input: User has staged changes to add a new authentication feature
output: Implement JWT-based authentication to secure API endpoints
- Add JWT token generation and validation
- Create login endpoint with token response
- Add authentication middleware for protected routes

best_practices: Stage only related changes together for focused commit messages
Review the generated message and adjust if needed before committing
Use the --scope flag to specify affected components for clarity
anti_patterns: Don't stage unrelated changes - split them into separate commits
Avoid using generic messages like 'update' or 'fix stuff'
Don't commit without reviewing the generated message first

faq.question: What git commands does this skill use?
faq.answer: It uses 'git diff --staged' to analyze changes and 'git log --oneline -10' to review recent commits

faq.question: Can I customize the commit message format?
faq.answer: The skill follows conventional commit standards but you can edit the generated message before committing

faq.question: Does it work with any git repository?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with any git repository as long as git is installed and you have staged changes

faq.question: How does it determine the commit type?
faq.answer: It analyzes your code changes and matches them to conventional commit types like feat, fix, docs, etc.

faq.question: What if I don't like the generated message?
faq.answer: You can always edit the message before committing or regenerate with different parameters

faq.question: Can it handle breaking changes?
faq.answer: Yes, it can include BREAKING CHANGE footers when significant API changes are detected
